quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Heidi delves deep into why change is actually good for your teams, why you're better off not having super stable teams, how to effectively execute reorgs, and through that, how to reduce attrition, stagnation, and knowledge silos.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive framing that team change can be beneficial and a lever to reduce common org pathologies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Heidi shares the five types of reteaming, anti-patterns to avoid when making org changes, what sort of team structure is most conducive to creating totally new products, why being transparent about your reorg plans is definitely worth considering.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights concrete frameworks (types of reteaming, anti-patterns, team structures) and a practical principle (transparency) practitioners can apply.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: After two decades in the tech industry, Heidi became fascinated with how teams are organized, how org structures change and how to set teams up for success through that change.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes the core problem space: designing teams and org structures to succeed through change.

quotes.topic_title: Why Heidi studied reteaming and reorgs
quotes.text: I had been working in a variety of different fast-growing startups for most of my career in 20 years in software-as-a-service companies in particular.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Establishes the depth of experience behind her perspective on why teams inevitably change in high-growth environments.

quotes.topic_title: Why Heidi studied reteaming and reorgs
quotes.text: a lot of the books I would read on teams and the advice that I would get from people would be, you really want to keep your teams the same. You want to go for that forming, storming, norming, performing kind of thing.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Highlights the conventional “stable teams” model she’s reacting to, setting up a contrast with dynamic reteaming.

quotes.topic_title: Why Heidi studied reteaming and reorgs
quotes.text: I had thought about that and I was like, wait, well it wasn't really possible for us when I was at a startup and I was the 10th employee and we grew to 900 people and now thousands of people, our team's kind of morphed and changed.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A concrete growth example showing why stable-team advice can be unrealistic in rapidly scaling organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Why Heidi studied reteaming and reorgs
quotes.text: So I feel like if you're in a fast-growing company or a shrinking company, look there, don't look at trying to fight the natural evolution.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to align team design with organizational change rather than resisting it.

quotes.topic_title: Why Heidi studied reteaming and reorgs
quotes.text: I was just trying to prove a point and to illustrate that teams change.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A succinct, memorable thesis statement that reframes team change as normal and expected.

quotes.topic_title: The overlooked people layer in product building
quotes.text: but there's also a lot of company building that happens in building the people structures and just when you go from one to many to a multitude, there's a lot of work that goes into it.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Highlights the often-missed idea that scaling requires intentionally designing people structures, not just shipping product.

quotes.topic_title: The overlooked people layer in product building
quotes.text: This is enablement type work and it's where I focused a lot of my time and my career helping make teams and organizations successful.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Names “enablement work” as a distinct, valuable discipline practitioners can invest in to improve team/org outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: The overlooked people layer in product building
quotes.text: I think it would be highly convenient if we could just focus on building products that people love and getting product market fit, talking to customers.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Contrasts the idealized product-only focus with the real-world need to handle the people layer.

quotes.topic_title: The overlooked people layer in product building
quotes.text: It would be great if it could only be that, but the reality is we're humans together and there's a lot of opportunity to build companies that delight people where they're excited to be included in decision-making about how the organization grows and changes or shrinks.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Connects organizational change to inclusion in decision-making as a lever for building a company people want to be part of.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency in reorgs and creating opportunities
quotes.text: I really like it when there's transparency in reorgs.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Sets the core principle that reorgs work better when leaders share plans openly rather than behind closed doors.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency in reorgs and creating opportunities
quotes.text: They visualized it on whiteboards and brought people over to the whiteboards to see the future team structure that the leaders wanted and they got input into the design.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for making org design tangible and inviting real feedback before changes are finalized.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency in reorgs and creating opportunities
quotes.text: So we rolled these whiteboards out and it had the team structure with everyone's names on it. It had the name of the team, the mission of the team, how many open slots for hiring across all of these different teams, and then people's names in their existing team positions.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A specific template for what to include to make reorgs legible and to surface internal mobility opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency in reorgs and creating opportunities
quotes.text: I think sometimes when you convene people for a meeting to talk about anything, it's good to have a starting point.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A practical facilitation principle: bring a draft plan to accelerate alignment and make feedback actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Transparency in reorgs and creating opportunities
quotes.text: But people can be delighted by working on things that another person doesn't think are particularly interesting.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Counters the assumption that unpopular work will stay unpopular—choice and visibility can reveal unexpected motivation matches.

quotes.topic_title: Making collaborative reorgs work: clarity and timeboxing
quotes.text: Sometimes we're going to have a say, we're going to be able to participate, sometimes we're not. And being clear on who the decision maker is in a change is really important.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Emphasizes decision clarity as the key enabler for collaborative change without stalling or confusion.

quotes.topic_title: Making collaborative reorgs work: clarity and timeboxing
quotes.text: There's another framework that I really like. I don't think it's in my book, but I've written about it in my new book, but it's called RIDE. And we had a chief people officer at Procore and she's now at UKG, Pat Wadors. She taught us the RIDE framework for decision making clarity and it's who's requesting the change, who can give input to the change, who's the decider on the change, and who's going to execute on the change? So it's like R-I-D-E.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete decision-making framework teams can use to define roles and reduce reorg ambiguity.

quotes.topic_title: Making collaborative reorgs work: clarity and timeboxing
quotes.text: You're getting acquired, you're probably not going to have a standup meeting and talk about should we get acquired or not? No, you're not part of that decision.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A crisp example that sets realistic boundaries on participation—some decisions aren’t up for group debate.

quotes.topic_title: Making collaborative reorgs work: clarity and timeboxing
quotes.text: Make a schedule biased towards shorter as opposed to longer. You don't want to deliberate on this forever, because especially as you include more people, it can be distracting. So you want to proceed as expediently as you can.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to timebox collaborative reorgs to minimize distraction and decision drag.

quotes.topic_title: Five patterns of reteaming and what “reorg” means
quotes.text: Okay, so the five patterns of reteaming. One by one, someone joins your company or someone leaves your company, grow and split. It's a growth pattern. Teams grow bigger and then they split into two or more teams. Opposite of grow and split is merging. Sometimes two or more teams merge together. It's more of a shrinking pattern. We might be seeing more of this these days as companies downsize. Things merge together and consolidate. Isolation is, or innovation by isolation. Start a new team off to the side, a beneficial silo, give that team process freedom, great for catalyzing new product lines within your existing company. Also great for emergencies and they just happen anyway if we have incidents and people have to come together, solve an incident and then go back to their teams. And switching. So switching is moving from one team to another team. You can do this at a variety of cadences, short term, long term.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Defines a practical five-pattern framework for understanding and planning how teams change over time.

quotes.topic_title: Five patterns of reteaming and what “reorg” means
quotes.text: I think reorg is a word that has very traditional baggage and connotations.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Reframes “reorg” as a loaded term, encouraging leaders to separate everyday team change from high-stakes organizational upheaval.

quotes.topic_title: Five patterns of reteaming and what “reorg” means
quotes.text: And when I was writing Dynamic Reteaming, it just didn't feel like an appropriate word to use for, well, Sue is looking to learn a little bit about how our web operations work, she's going to move to that team.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example showing that many team changes are small, learning-driven moves—not “reorgs.”

quotes.topic_title: Five patterns of reteaming and what “reorg” means
quotes.text: Reorganization is a traditional word. It implies on the large, it implies top-down changes that you have say no. It's something different than what I consider reteaming, which is these five patterns that happen at different levels.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Clarifies a key distinction: “reorg” suggests large, top-down change, while reteaming is a multi-level, ongoing set of patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation pattern story: Expertcity pivot to GoToMyPC
quotes.text: Heidi, stop working on the marketplace. We're not going to do that product anymore. We're killing it because nobody's buying it and made six bucks or something last month.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A concrete example of using clear market feedback to decisively kill a product rather than letting it linger as a “pause.”

quotes.topic_title: Isolation pattern story: Expertcity pivot to GoToMyPC
quotes.text: And so I was invited to be at this team off to the side and there was a small team and we didn't have to do waterfall software development. We were freed from that. We were liberated from that.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Shows the isolation pattern as a deliberate structural move: carve out a small team and remove heavyweight process to enable speed.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation pattern story: Expertcity pivot to GoToMyPC
quotes.text: So taking a team off to the side, giving that team process freedom. They didn't want us distracted from the drag.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on why isolation works: protect the new initiative from the operational pull of the existing product line.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation pattern story: Expertcity pivot to GoToMyPC
quotes.text: Again, it's going against green of what some of these books say, oh, you want to desilo everything? No, sometimes there's a reason why you have a problem. You want to solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A contrarian take that “beneficial silos” can be the right tool when solving urgent or innovation-critical problems.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation pattern story: Expertcity pivot to GoToMyPC
quotes.text: When you're working on an existing product line, you get this cadence and it can become a mature cadence. Maybe people work in two weeks or one week now, but when you're working on something new, you need faster iteration loops.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A practical mental model for matching team structure and process to the type of work: mature products tolerate slower cadence; new bets require faster loops.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a successful “startup within a company”
quotes.text: And so, one, isolate the team or put them in a different area.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A simple, concrete tactic for making an internal startup actually behave like a startup by reducing ambient interference.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a successful “startup within a company”
quotes.text: Number two, tell other people not to disturb this team. That's key. And hearing it from a leader is really, really important. No, you're not going to pull them into something else. They're working on this other thing.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Highlights executive-enforced protection as a prerequisite for focus and momentum in an incubated team.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a successful “startup within a company”
quotes.text: you want people pairing and switching pairs so they're not single owners of the system.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A practical ownership model that prevents bottlenecks and makes it feasible to move people into (and out of) the isolated team.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a successful “startup within a company”
quotes.text: Ideally they report up to someone that really has decision-making authority and decisions won't get reversed.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Defines a governance requirement—clear, durable decision rights—to avoid innovation being stalled by organizational backtracking.

quotes.topic_title: How to run a successful “startup within a company”
quotes.text: SecureDocs became separate and then it grew from there. And then it became this wonderful successful product that was recently acquired.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A concrete example showing the “startup within a company” pattern can work and even spin out into an acquisition outcome.

quotes.text: What you may not know is that there's a free version that was made with small website owners in mind.

quotes.text: It also performs automated site audits to find what issues prevent your website from ranking higher on Google.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: Suggests a repeatable methodology—automated audits—to systematically uncover and address ranking blockers.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation caveats: how it can fail
quotes.text: I feel like to me one of the most important ones you've talked to. And this is having an executive essentially sponsoring this team and supporting and protecting it versus some managers just like, now we're going to go do this off to the side, because otherwise no one's going to really take that seriously.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the practical requirement of executive sponsorship to make an isolated team credible and effective.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation caveats: how it can fail
quotes.text: I'll also say that things don't always succeed a hundred percent.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A caution that isolation patterns are not guaranteed wins and should be approached with realistic expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation caveats: how it can fail
quotes.text: I've seen isolated teams within companies where someone has the opportunity to sell something, they talk to their friends who are the engineers who build the feature for them, but then it leaves something for other people to maintain later and they weren't involved in the decisions.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Gives a concrete failure mode: isolated delivery can create downstream maintenance burdens and resentment when others are excluded from decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation caveats: how it can fail
quotes.text: It's like kind of like balconies and basements.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for how organizational patterns can create hidden upsides/downsides if not managed intentionally.

quotes.topic_title: Isolation caveats: how it can fail
quotes.text: The tree is going to drop the leaves and you got to sweep them up.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A vivid metaphor emphasizing that organizational change creates ongoing operational work that must be planned for.

quotes.topic_title: Tips for the other reteaming patterns
quotes.text: So one by one, someone joins your company or they leave your company. So the tip with one by one is when someone joins, help them feel a sense of belonging, and you can do that through not having their first day be them sitting over there alone. You could have someone have a first pair.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Practical onboarding advice that emphasizes belonging and immediate pairing to reduce isolation and speed integration.

quotes.topic_title: Tips for the other reteaming patterns
quotes.text: So you need to pay attention to the new hires that are joining, help them feel a sense of belonging, get them to talk about themselves, which is said to increase their sense of connection and retention. There's some research in the book The Culture Code by Daniel Coyle, which talks about that.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable retention tactic backed by a cited source: structured self-disclosure to build connection.

quotes.topic_title: Tips for the other reteaming patterns
quotes.text: So when the team gets bigger, facilitation and communication tends to break down. So some signals that teams might bring up when they feel like a change might be helpful is the meetings are taking longer. You're in that case where it's harder to make decisions. It was easier when there were like five of us, but now they're 13. The work becomes divergent.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A clear set of diagnostic signals for when “grow and split” may be needed as teams scale.

quotes.topic_title: Tips for the other reteaming patterns
quotes.text: Sometimes splitting though can create dependencies that weren't there when you were together as one team. So you inherit other problems or you might inherit challenges like, all right, the team decides it's far effective if they split into two or three, but we just have one product manager, we just have one designer. We just have one person who helps us anticipate quality challenges. So it's a lot of problem trading when you do a lot of this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that splitting can introduce new coordination bottlenecks and role constraints—it's “problem trading,” not a free win.

quotes.topic_title: Tips for the other reteaming patterns
quotes.text: One activity I do like to do with teams that merge is called story of our team. That's in chapter 13 of the second edition. So with story of our team, each team makes a timeline of... They stand in order of when they joined their team and they make a timeline with milestones of when they joined their team, when people left, and significant events and things they created that they're excited about and that they're proud of.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A concrete merging methodology (shared history timelines) to build mutual understanding and cohesion after consolidation.

quotes.topic_title: No perfect org: problem trading and leadership stance
quotes.text: We have this challenge today. We decide, oh, there's a few ways we could handle this. Pros and cons of each solution. It's like the Toyota Kata, like grasp the current condition. You'll experience you have challenges. What's the next evolution or the next target condition? How might you get there?
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Offers a practical iterative improvement framework (Toyota Kata) for navigating org design tradeoffs under changing conditions.

quotes.topic_title: No perfect org: problem trading and leadership stance
quotes.text: We're always transforming from the current state to the future state.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes org design as continuous transformation rather than a one-time “perfect” solution.

quotes.topic_title: No perfect org: problem trading and leadership stance
quotes.text: So to that, I would ask people, well, how do you want that to be? And how do you want to show up and be as a leader?
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable prompt for leaders to choose an intentional stance (directive vs participatory) when making team/org changes.

quotes.topic_title: No perfect org: problem trading and leadership stance
quotes.text: Or is it a little bit where you get people's input? And that in itself, you got to weigh what you're dealing with, again.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Highlights the tradeoff-based decision of when and how much to involve people, rather than assuming participation is always feasible.

quotes.topic_title: No perfect org: problem trading and leadership stance
quotes.text: Let's involve them in some of the org decisions that are going to be part of their daily life.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Concrete guidance to include teams in decisions that directly affect their day-to-day work, improving buy-in and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Reteaming anti-patterns: percentages and spreading stars
quotes.text: We did that in Waterfall like many years ago, but that doesn't really work.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Challenges the common practice of fractional allocation by pointing out it’s a legacy approach that fails in modern team settings.

quotes.topic_title: Reteaming anti-patterns: percentages and spreading stars
quotes.text: It's very hard for people to multitask and be involved in multiple efforts at once. It's hard for the brain with all the context switching that needs to happen in that case. So I call that the percentage anti-pattern.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Names and explains a concrete anti-pattern practitioners can watch for: splitting people across projects creates a context-switching tax.

quotes.topic_title: Reteaming anti-patterns: percentages and spreading stars
quotes.text: Reteaming or having people suddenly show up and you weren't expecting them or suddenly they're gone and there's no communication around it whatsoever, that's another anti-pattern.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Actionable warning that surprise staffing changes without communication are harmful and should be treated as an explicit anti-pattern.

quotes.topic_title: Reteaming anti-patterns: percentages and spreading stars
quotes.text: Like let's just spread the people from that team across the other ones and then we'll have that. And it didn't work. He didn't have that. It didn't happen.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: A specific example showing that “spreading high performers” doesn’t replicate team magic and can backfire.

quotes.topic_title: Reteaming anti-patterns: percentages and spreading stars
quotes.text: So John felt like he essentially destroyed that when he split up that team.
quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.context: Memorable caution that breaking up a high-performing team can destroy the chemistry that made it effective.
